ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Persian L3 helped improve my reading and writing skills in the language. We spent considerable time writing in Persian, far more than we had in previous semesters. We also learned a lot about Persian culture.
I learned a comprehensive level of Persian language, grammar, and culture.
I learned a lot of new vocab and grammar structures to improve my writing in Persian. I also learned about important historical spots and traditions.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengthens: requires lots of practice and engagement to help learn the language. Learning Iranian culture and history an added bonus and improved vocabulary for speaking.

Weaknesses: a lot of work that was sometimes difficult to keep up with. At times feeling like not enough emphasis was being placed on speaking the language vs reading/writing.
The course is wonderful in that you truly learn the language. But , expect for it to be a lot of work.

The strength is that the professors insane amount of work will force you to become a good writer. The downside is that its an absurd amount of work for an L3 language. She often times assigns assignments that are 2 hours long at like 8pm the day proceeding, and therefore, youre left with no time to complete them. Also, there is no grade transparency. She is also a tough grader. You also wont really improve any elements of your speaking.

Strengths are that we had constant exposure to new sources of Persian and the small class size helped each person participate. One major weakness was that my class was full of native speakers, so there were many times during class where I had no idea what was going on because I was surrounded by fluent conversation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For students interested in intensely learning the Persian language I would recommend the class.
Yes, if you want to learn Persian, especially reading and writing
Yes. If you are interested in learning the Persian language, this is the way to go.

Honestly I would not. I think there are more fun languages you can take here at Yale that have less work and are more rewarding. You dont get the chance to learn much about the beautiful parts of modern Persian culture because youre always learning about super old traditions and things that arent applicable to modern Iran. Also you wont really spend any time working on your speaking, which for me as a native speaker was very frustrating, as my goal was to improve my speaking for when I speak with family.

If you'd like to learn Persian at Yale, you have no choice, but it may be better to take it online or in grad school if you have that option. At Yale there's a large chance you'll end up with a ton of native speakers, and if Persian if your principal concern perhaps that would be a help, but if you can't dedicate a ton of extra study it's a hindrance.
